skill.name: slb
skill.description: Simultaneous Launch Button - Two-person rule for destructive commands in multi-agent workflows. Risk-tiered classification, command hash binding, 5 execution gates, client-side execution with environment inheritance. Go CLI.
skill.summary: Simultaneous Launch Button - Two-person rule for destructive commands in multi-agent workflows. Risk...
skill.author: Dicklesworthstone

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing no executable code. The SKILL.md describes a Go CLI tool for safety. No file access, network calls, command execution, or environment variable access is performed by the skill itself.

content.user_title: Add safety checks for destructive commands
content.value_statement: AI agents can run destructive commands that cause irreversible damage. This skill implements a two-person rule requiring peer approval before executing risky commands like rm, git push --force, or DROP TABLE.
actual_capabilities: Classifies commands into CRITICAL, DANGEROUS, CAUTION, and SAFE tiers
Requires peer approval for destructive commands
Binds commands to SHA-256 hashes to prevent tampering
Captures rollback state before executing risky commands
limitations: Does not execute commands itself - integrates with external Go CLI tool
Requires manual installation of the SLB Go binary
Does not prevent commands outside of the SLB workflow

use_cases.title: Protect production deployments
use_cases.description: Require team approval before running kubectl delete or terraform destroy in production environments

use_cases.title: Prevent AI data loss
use_cases.description: Add safety gates so multiple AI agents must approve rm, DROP TABLE, or git reset --hard commands

use_cases.title: Audit dangerous operations
use_cases.description: Log all destructive commands and require human or peer AI review before execution

prompt_templates.title: Check command safety
prompt_templates.scenario: Verify if a command requires approval
prompt_templates.prompt: Check what tier this command falls under using SLB patterns test: <command>

prompt_templates.title: Request approval
prompt_templates.scenario: Submit a command for peer review
prompt_templates.prompt: Run slb request "<command>" --reason "<reason>" and show me the request ID

prompt_templates.title: Approve request
prompt_templates.scenario: Review and approve a pending request
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me all pending SLB requests with slb pending --all-projects, then review request <request-id>

prompt_templates.title: Execute safely
prompt_templates.scenario: Run a command through the approval workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Run slb run "<command>" --reason "<reason>" --session-id <session-id> and wait for approval

output: Use slb run to request approval

best_practices: Initialize SLB in each project directory before running AI agents
Use different AI models for requester and reviewer when possible
Configure rollback capture for CRITICAL tier commands
anti_patterns: Running destructive commands outside the SLB workflow
Self-approving requests without actual peer review

faq.question: Which AI tools work with SLB?
faq.answer: SLB integrates with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code through hook installations and manual commands

faq.question: What happens if the daemon is unreachable?
faq.answer: SLB falls back to file-based polling. Dangerous commands are blocked until the daemon is available

faq.question: Can I bypass approval in emergencies?
faq.answer: Yes, use emergency-execute with hash acknowledgment. All bypasses are extensively logged

faq.question: Is my data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No. SLB runs locally and commands execute in your shell environment with full environment inheritance

faq.question: What commands are always blocked?
faq.answer: Commands matching CRITICAL patterns like rm -rf /, DROP DATABASE, and terraform destroy require 2+ approvals

faq.question: How does SLB compare to similar tools?
faq.answer: Unlike git protection or container guards, SLB works across all command types and supports multi-agent peer review
